history.content:
Depends on what kind of hardware you're focusing on.

As always, take CS 170: Algorithms because it applies to practically all fields of EECS.

Classes to take pursuing any sort of hardware:

EE 105: Microelectronics

EECS 149: Embedded Systems

EECS 151/LA/LB: Digital Design and Integrated Circuits Lab

If you're pursuing computer architecture, some good upper div classes would be:

CS 152: Computer Architecture

CS 161: Cybersecurity

CS 162: Operating Systems

If you're pursuing circuit design:

EE 120: Signals and Systems

EE 130: Integrated Circuits

EE 140: Linear Integrated Circuits

Depends on what kind of hardware you're focusing on.

As always, take CS 170: Algorithms because it applies to practically all fields of EECS.

EE 105: Microelectronics is for anyone pursuing any sort of hardware. EECS 149: Embedded Systems is also a good class. EECS 151/LA/LB: Digital Design and Integrated Circuits Lab covers a lot for hardware as well.

If you're pursuing computer architecture, some good upper div classes would be:

CS 152: Computer Architecture

CS 161: Cybersecurity

CS 162: Operating Systems

If you're pursuing circuit design:

EE 120: Signals and Systems

EE 130: Integrated Circuits

EE 140: Linear Integrated Circuits

Depends on what kind of hardware you're focusing on.

As always, take CS 170: Algorithms because it applies to practically all fields of EECS.

EE 105: Microelectronics is for anyone pursuing any sort of hardware. EECS 149: Embedded Systems is also a good class. EECS 151/LA/LB: Digital Design and Integrated Circuits Lab covers a lot for hardware as well.

If you're pursuing computer architecture, some good upper div classes would be:

CS 152: Computer Architecture

CS 161: Cybersecurity

CS 162: Operating Systems

If you're pursuing circuit design:

EE 130: Integrated Circuits

EE 140: Linear Integrated Circuits

Depends on what kind of hardware you're focusing on.

As always, take CS 170: Algorithms because it applies to practically all fields of EECS.

EE 105: Microelectronics is for anyone pursuing any sort of hardware. EECS 149: Embedded Systems is also a good class. EECS 151/LA/LB: Digital Design and Integrated Circuits Lab covers a lot for hardware as well.

If you're pursuing computer architecture a some good upper div classes would be:

CS 152: Computer Architecture

CS 161: Cybersecurity

CS 162: Operating Systems

If you're pursuing circuit design:

EE 130: Integrated Circuits

EE 140: Linear Integrated Circuits

children.subject: Thank you so much for your generous advices. I learn a lot today.

The student answer is pretty good for the most part, but, I'd argue that you, as a transfer student, might need to prioritize one subfield over all others since you have so little time here (two years and even an extra semester really aren't sufficient to explore everything you might want to within EECS here). i believe transfer students must take most, if not all, EECS lower divs here, so you might face a crunch in prioritizing which upper divs to take first or at all. I think CS majors must take a certain number of "CS" labelled UD classes, so taking CS 170 might be useful from that perspective, but when it comes to understanding material in hardware classes or getting you closer to doing research in hardware (which has the potential to be the most important part of any application to a graduate program in computer hardware or VLSI or something of that flavor) I'll say that CS 170 will not directly help you achieve any of that. If you haven't taken/satisfied the EECS lower divs yet, CS 61C in particular should tell you definitively whether you want to take the systems/computer architecture path outlined above (the class typically engenders strong feelings one way or another), while the EE 16 series will give a very basic introduction to circuits that should tell you whether you're interested enough in them to spend a few years dedicated to their study, after which EE 105 should provide a solid foundation moving forward (or entirely break your confidence, at which point you might be glad you took CS 170). Best of luck!

history.content:
Hi everyone,

I hope all of you are having a very great day.
I am a junior transfer student as CS major. However, I aim to have a EECS master degree studying more about electronics development. I am wondering what courses I should take to be a qualified undergraduate EE student preparing his master degree. 
I have made half of the plan for my software field. Now I am confused with the EE part. Please help me out.
Thank you very much!
history.subject: What hardware courses needed to take before applying for EECS master?
